meta.title: Living Machines: A Handbook of Research in Biomimetic and Biohybrid Systems
meta.author: Tony J. Prescott, Nathan F. Lepora, Paul F. M. J. Verschure

parts.title: Living Machines: Bridging Nature and Technology
parts.body: The book "Living Machines: A Handbook of Research in Biomimetic and Biohybrid Systems," edited by Tony J. Prescott, Nathan F. Lepora, and Paul F. M.J. Verschure, explores the concept of "living machines", which are human-made devices that emulate capabilities found in nature. These machines strive to bridge biological systems and technological advancements. The book addresses the complex challenges of replicating natural materials, organism structure, and behavior, emphasizing the importance of synergy between engineering and biological research. Key features of living machines include autonomy, adaptability, and interdisciplinary collaboration to create sustainable and efficient technologies for an evolving world.

parts.title: Autonomous Robots with Microbial Fuel Cells
parts.body: Researchers are striving to create autonomous robots powered by sustainable energy sources. Traditional robots rely on batteries or mains power, but Microbial Fuel Cells (MFCs) offer a novel alternative. MFCs use microorganisms to convert organic substrates into electricity, providing energy to symbiotic robots (SymBots). These robots, unlike typical robots, involve a true integration of living microbes with mechatronic systems, allowing robots to be self-sustaining. The aim is for these robots to autonomously collect nutrients from their environment and maintain their operation without human intervention, mimicking a form of natural metabolism.

parts.title: Audition and Sound Processing in the Brain
parts.body: Audition is about sensing and interpreting pressure waves to identify and locate sound sources. The auditory system includes the outer, middle, and inner ear, processing sound waves into auditory nerve spikes in the organ of Corti. The sound is then processed through a series of nuclei in the brainstem and mid-brain to the cortex, also affected by other sensory inputs. Sound reaches the ears both directly and after interacting with surfaces, modifying sound due to variations in the head-related transfer function (HRTF). At the ear drum, sound is impedance matched and transferred to the cochlea, where the pressure is measured by inner hair cells and sound is split into different frequencies. This process results in compression to manage loud sounds, and the auditory nerve transfers information to the brain's nucleus complexes for further sound processing.

parts.title: Adhesive Mechanisms in Nature: Gecko and Beetle Systems
parts.body: Gecko lizards, beetles, and other animals have unique attachment systems allowing them to effortlessly move on various surfaces using micro and nano-scale hairy structures. Geckos have hierarchical foot hairs composed of microscale setae that split into smaller spatulas. These spatulas generate strong adhesion using van der Waals forces and facilitate intimate contact with surfaces, even under low pressure, due to their thin structure. These slanted setae also provide anisotropic adhesion, meaning they can adhere strongly in one direction and release easily in another. Further, they exhibit superhydrophobic and self-cleaning properties. Meanwhile, beetles have mushroom-shaped pads on their feet and a unique wing-locking mechanism utilizing interlocking microstructures for strong yet reversible adhesion, suitable for diverse conditions, including waxy or wet surfaces.

parts.title: Key Concepts in Biomimetic Decision-Making Systems
parts.body: Biomimetic systems have harnessed these principles for autonomous decision making in artificial systems. One application is in robotics, where perceptual hyperacuity enables robots to detect small spatial or temporal differences with high precision (similar to human tactile sensations). Artificial intelligence (AI) uses decision thresholds to allow machines to make rapid choices, emulating human-like decision-making processes in complex environments. Swarm robotics, inspired by collective behavior in nature, exemplifies how individual, simple robots can achieve sophisticated outcomes through collaboration. They mirror collective decision making in insects, achieving tasks like exploration and aggregation efficiently without central control. Future expansions in these areas may lead to robots capable of perceiving and navigating intricate environments as adeptly as living organisms, through enhanced decision-making algorithms that accumulate sensory evidence to make informed and timely decisions.

parts.title: Understanding Emotions and Physiological Regulation in Organisms
parts.body: Emotions are associated with feelings and moods, involving experiences with distinct intensities and qualities. They arise from an appraisal of situations or stimuli related to needs and goals—a complex interplay of components like thoughts, action tendencies, bodily reactions, and facial expressions. Importantly, emotions differ from motivations, being transient responses to external stimuli, not always tied to internal needs. Physiological regulation in organisms involves homeostasis, which maintains internal stability / balance through reactive feedback, and allostasis, a dynamic adjustment of regulatory systems through anticipation and learning. Emotional states can influence learning and behavior, acting as communicative signals and shaping social interactions. Different theories—including drive, incentive, and humanistic theories—provide frameworks to understand motivation, describing it as striving to satisfy biological needs and achieve balance. Conversely, emotions offer a broader influence, affecting cognition and social dynamics and are linked to brain structures like the amygdala and insula.

parts.title: Soft Bodied Locomotion in Invertebrates and Biomimetic Insights
parts.body: Animals primarily use soft materials for locomotion despite their complex movement patterns, as seen in species like caterpillars. Unlike vertebrates with hard skeletons, these soft-bodied organisms utilize an environmental skeleton, where external elements like surfaces provide support. Segment contraction and turgor pressure help in movement by transmitting compressive forces onto substrates. For instance, the Manduca sexta caterpillar uses its body fluid pressure modestly while placing reliance on abdominal segment contractions to move. Caterpillars lack circular muscles and do not maintain constant body volume as annelids do, instead focusing on mechanical advantages provided by the interaction between body mechanics and substrate. Research has shown that caterpillars generate a wave-like motion along their body, which allows them to crawl by moving in a manner where muscle activation patterns create movement harmoniously with environmental interactions rather than relying extensively on internal body pressure for shape manipulation.

parts.title: Non-Invasive Brain–Machine Interfaces
parts.body:
Title: Non-Invasive Brain–Machine Interfaces

Invasive BMI (e.g., electrodes implanted in the cortex) gives way to non-invasive methods using techniques like EEG and MEG which measure cortical activity. A BMI uses pattern recognition for acquisition, feature extraction, and classification. Key challenges include dealing with non-stationary brainwave dynamics. Applications involve neuromuscular alternative communication and neurorehabilitation for brain plasticity enhancement in paralyzed limb movement. EEG is widely used due to accessibility, but MEG and hemodynamics also play a role. Learning and adapting to EEG changes is crucial for BMI functionality, urging progress toward practical use.

parts.title: Human Augmentation Overview
parts.body: Human augmentation involves exocortical devices like smartphones, pharmaceuticals, and prosthetics to enhance human capabilities. This includes improvements in physical, cognitive, and sensory abilities, extending health and longevity, and even augmenting emotional and moral capacities. For example, prosthetic limbs allow direct control from nerves, and cognitive enhancement progresses with pharmaceuticals. Future technologies, like nanorobots, promise even more profound enhancements, potentially surpassing organic limits and transforming social systems.

parts.title: Living Machines and Sustainability
parts.body: Living Machines and their sustainability are critical in addressing climate change due to greenhouse gases from current energy sources and the materials needed for modern technology. Current technologies like AI and robotics face energy inefficiencies and limits due to transistor manufacturing reaching physical and economic constraints. The solution may lie in a biomimetic and biohybrid approach, mimicking natural processes and materials for sustainable design. This includes considering biogeochemical cycles used by living systems and utilizing common elements to ensure long-term sustainability.
